utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Did you hear about this study that found people that were cool and popular at 13 have problems succeeding later in life?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hmm. I’m doing okay, and I was very popular at 13.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: In school?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, no. At home. The servants would sing to me, laugh at my jokes. I wish I knew their names.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Does the study say what happens to the unpopular kids?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You tell me, you woke up in bed with one.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Listen to this. I just received an e-mail from Wil Wheaton. Leonard Nimoy’s son is working on a documentary that he started with his father before he passed away. It’s about Mr. Spock and his impact on our culture.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Why is he writing to you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, they’re looking for fans to interview, and Wil thought I’d be good for it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh. Hey, high five.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Absolutely not. Yeah, Penny, you spent some time in front of the camera. Any words of advice?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yes. Don’t take your shirt off just because the director said so.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: This is a documentary about Mr. Spock. I’m sure if there’s nudity, it will be tasteful.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hey. You got a minute?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Not really. Visigoths are kind of up my butt right now.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Pause the game, Howard.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Howard? Uh-oh. Make room, Visigoths. ‘Sup?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: We need to talk about redecorating this place.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, no, not this again.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Look, I get that you grew up here and you’re attached to things looking a certain way, but I want this to feel like my house, too.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, honey, of course it’s your house. Why else would you be cleaning it all the time?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: All right. Let’s start over. I’m redecorating. The furniture, the carpeting, the walls. I’m changing everything that depresses me when I look at it. Try not to be one of those things.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: May I say something?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Is it about how I can’t have new wallpaper ’cause your dad left when you were little and your mom died?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Never mind.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (on phone)
utterance.content: Hello, Amy. It’s Sheldon. Yeah, I, I know that we’re broken up, but I’m leaving this message because I thought perhaps you’d like to watch me be interviewed for a documentary about Mr. Spock. Or as I like to call it, a Spockumentary. Yeah, I’m going to use that joke in the interview, so try to laugh like you’re hearing it for the first time. You know, hysterically, hmm? And with a tinge of sadness that I’m no longer in your life.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I’m the one who thought of Spockumentary.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: And I’m laughing like I did the first time I heard it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (answering door)
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Wil Wheaton
utterance.content: Hey, Sheldon. This is Adam Nimoy.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Nice to meet you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, it’s nice to meet you. I admire your father’s work very much. It’s not every day I get to meet someone whose life’s journey began in my hero’s scrotum.

utterance.speaker: Wil
utterance.content: I told you. This guy is gold.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Whatcha doing?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh. Making myself a bologna sandwich like my mom used to make me after my dad left, but before she died.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Okay, listen, I’m thinking that maybe we can compromise on the house.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’m listening.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Let’s just redo one room and see how it goes.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That is reasonable. But what room?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: How ’bout this one?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No way. No, this is the room I associate the most with my mom.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Then how ’bout the bathroom?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I want to change my answer.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Fine. Then the dining room.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I guess we didn’t use it very often. Unless we had company. Which didn’t happen much after my dad left and not at all after my mom…

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Great. I’m gonna go pick out paint samples.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: All right, we’re just gonna have a conversation. Pretend the camera’s not here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right. But this better not be some elaborate scheme to get me out of my shirt.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How long have you known Adam?

utterance.speaker: Wil
utterance.content: A few years.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: And what are you getting him back for?

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Let’s start with your name and occupation.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Dr. Sheldon Cooper, theoretical physicist, Caltech.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: And what is your earliest memory of the character Spock?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The first episode of Star Trek: The Original Series I ever saw was The Galileo Seven. Uh, Spock had just landed on the planet Taurus II. Then my brother came in, sat on my head, and said eat farts. After that day, I was hooked. On Star Trek, not my brother’s sphincter-based cuisine.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: What was it about Spock that appealed to you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I think the same thing that appeals to people everywhere, the dream of a cold, rational world entirely without human emotion. Spock came from a planet governed only by logic. You know, on Vulcan, when your brother asks, why are you hitting yourself? the answer is, I’m not. You’re moving my arm. To which he says, Fascinating. And then you both watch educational television.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Aw. When he says things like that, I just want to hug him and make everything better.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: My brother was mean to me, too.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, you probably had it coming.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Do you have any Spock collectibles?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I have many. My most treasured is an autographed napkin given to me by my very thoughtful friend Penny. That’s her over there.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hi. Look at that. I’m in a movie, my shirt stayed on.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Can we see the napkin?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course. Excuse me. This will just take a moment.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: When did we get a wall safe?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: When there was no more room in the floor safe.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: When did we get a floor safe?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: When we got the security camera.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: There’s a security camera?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Aquaman, protecting your home since 2012.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, my God. We’ve done things on that couch.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah. You don’t have to tell me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: So, your father-in-law is in there right now?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yes. So back me up. The house is good the way it is.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, okay. Got it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey. What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Hey, Raj. Dad and I were just talking about taking down this wall.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You sure? It’s a pretty great wall.

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: What’s so great about it?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I did what I could.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Seriously? You brought Raj over to take your side?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Your dad’s on your side.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: He’s not on my side. He’s doing all the work for free.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: That is so generous of you. I’d like to switch sides.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Look, uh, I don’t even think you can take this wall down ’cause it’s load-bearing.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Well, it’s easy to find out. Just go into the crawlspace under the house and check.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: When is your visa up?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not only is it signed to me but this is where he wiped his mouth. So we are currently in the presence of Leonard Nimoy’s DNA.

utterance.speaker: Wil
utterance.content: Um, doesn’t Adam count as Leonard Nimoy’s DNA?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No offence, but this is pure 100% Nimoy. Because of your mother, you’re only 50%. Which isn’t bad, but anything that you wipe your mouth on gets thrown away.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, enough about the napkin. What else you hiding in there?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Wouldn’t you like to know?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I would.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: All right then. See? Just my valuables. My passport, uh, my will.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You have a will?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah. My 1/18 scale Wil Wheaton action figure. I also have the other kind of will, and in it I will my Wil back to Wil.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Will Wil want it?

utterance.speaker: Wil
utterance.content: Wil won’t.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, what’s that ring box?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh. That is an engagement ring that I was going to give my girlfriend Amy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You bought her a ring?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no. This has been in my family for generations. Except for a short time when Comanches cut off my great-great-great-grandmother’s finger and stole it.

utterance.speaker: Wil
utterance.content: Sheldon, that’s awful.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. The Texas Rangers tracked them down to their village and slaughtered every last one of them. It was a happy ending. Well, for my nine-fingered Nana.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Okay, back to the ring. Does Amy even know about this?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. She broke up with me before I could broach the subject.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, man, I’m sorry, that must have been devastating for you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, not at all. No, I’m fine. You know, Amy had reservations about our relationship, so all worked out for the best.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I know. It just…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (shouting)
utterance.content: I said I’m fine! We’ve gotten a little off-topic. Allow me to make things entertaining again in this little Spockumentary. That was Leonard’s joke. As a child, when faced with a dilemma, my mother encouraged me to ask what would Jesus do? The answer to that was always love thy neighbour. But my neighbour had a dead tooth, so that wasn’t going to happen. But that’s why I changed it to, what would Spock do?

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Did you find that helpful?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes. Oh, for example, three years ago when I discovered Penny was eating all my Pop-Tarts, instead of getting angry or vindictive, you know, I got a floor safe.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I knew I could smell ’em.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: What about from when you were a kid?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, certainly. Uh, when I was eight years old, Billy Sparks cornered me in the playground. I asked myself what would Spock do? Then I grabbed Billy on his shoulder and performed my first Vulcan nerve pinch.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: Did it work?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, no, he broke my collarbone. I can still hear it click.

utterance.speaker: Adam
utterance.content: That must have been very upsetting for you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, not at all. As I said, the entire point of emulating Spock was to rise above human emotion, which I’ve spent a lifetime mastering.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh pfft.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I’m not here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. You went pfft. What does pfft mean?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Um.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You did go pfft.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: All right, fine. Well, Sheldon, I’m no expert, but aren’t you completely missing the point of Spock? I mean, he liked to act like he had no emotions, but he was still half human.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just like you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m just saying, you pretend you don’t, but you have feelings just like everybody else.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not true. No, look at me. I had an engagement ring to give a girl, and instead, she rejected me. And am I emotional about that? No. No, I am sitting here on a couch, talking about my favourite TV character like nothing happened. ‘Cause I am just like him, all logical, all the time.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sweetie, you’re yelling.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Because when I speak at a regular volume, no one seems to believe me that I’ve put this Amy nonsense behind me.

utterance.speaker: Wil
utterance.content: This documentary is gonna be awesome.

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: You gonna be okay down here?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah. Yeah, I feel like an archaeologist. Indiana Jones and the Single-Family Dwelling. Hey. Look. Found a seashell.

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s a rat skull.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Relax. There’s enough droppings down here without you making more.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sorry. Do you have a sense of where we are?

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Yeah. I think that’s the den.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh. Okay, so we must be under the dining room.

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Uh-huh. Yep. You know, I know you don’t want to hear this, but it wouldn’t take that much work to turn that den into a nursery.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Why wouldn’t I want to hear it?

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: ‘Cause Bernie said you didn’t want kids.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That’s not true at all. I wish she’d get pregnant, believe me. I’m climbing on top of her every chance I get. In a loving and respectful manner. The point is, I really do want kids.

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Huh.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t know why she’s lying to you. She’s the one who doesn’t want kids. In fact, every time I bring up the subject…

utterance.speaker: Bernadette (above)
utterance.content: Earthquake.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh, my God, we’re gonna die.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Aftershock.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I can’t believe Sheldon was gonna ask Amy to marry him.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I know. I also can’t believe he watched what we did on that couch and still sits on it.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hello.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, buddy. How you doing?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Better. Did Wil and Adam leave?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Do you think they’re going to put my outburst in the documentary?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, yeah.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Definitely.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, there’s no point in dwelling on it. As the Vulcans say, Kup-fun-tor ha’kiv na’ish Du stau.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Do you know what that means?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Are you telling the truth?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Nirsh.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, this is ridiculous. Being upset about Amy all the time isn’t accomplishing anything. If I want to resolve this situation, then I need to take action.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What are you gonna do?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’m going to find her and ask her to marry me. And if she says yes, we can put this behind us and resume our relationship. And if she says no, well, then she can just ponfo miran.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: He didn’t meant that.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: So I should probably explain why I kind of fibbed.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That would be nice.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I told my dad that you were the one who didn’t want kids because I didn’t want to disappoint him.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: But you were okay throwing me under the bus?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Turns out yeah, I didn’t think twice about it.

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: Bernie, you don’t need to worry about me. But I don’t want to see you miss out. Raising children was the most rewarding experience of my life.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Oh, please. Mom did everything. All you did was come home from work, sit on the couch and drink beer. How is that raising kids?

utterance.speaker: Mr Rostenkowski
utterance.content: This is really a conversation for husband and wife. I’m gonna go clean up, hit the road. If your mother asks, I was here till ten.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s interesting your father didn’t help around the house and Howard doesn’t help, either, so in a way, Howard’s not only like your father, but he’s also like the child that you’re afraid to have.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Why are you still here?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Fine, I’ll leave. But it sounds like somebody needs a fresh diaper.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: All right, I admit that I don’t help out a lot. And I need to work on that. But if we had a kid, it would be different.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Because when my dad left, I promised myself that if I ever had a chance to be a father I’d always be there.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Okay, I’ll think about it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: And this an actual I’ll think about it, not like the can we get a motorcycle with a sidecar I’ll think about it”?

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: It’s an actual I’ll think about it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I really believe I’d be a great dad.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: I know you would.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Speaking of making babies, what do you say I wash up and poke around your crawlspace?

utterance.speaker: Kirk (on screen)
utterance.content: Dr. Dana feels he isn’t that dangerous. What makes you right and a trained psychiatrist wrong?

utterance.speaker: Spock (on screen)
utterance.content: Because she feels. I don’t. All I know is logic.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yeah, right. You can just shut your feelings off. There goes television, lying to us again. We let you raise our children, and this is the thanks we get. Leonard, how could I have been so foolish to try and follow in the footsteps of a made-up alien race with no emotions?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well now instead of idolizing fictional characters, you can focus on the real people who are already in your life.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Those are very wise words.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: They’d just be so much more comforting if they came out of a television.
